PTB-N-001-02.description:
Dated: March 3, 1974



I heard the sirens again today.

Harold dismisses it as 'routine checks,' but he forgets I grew up around the mines. I know the sound of panic when I hear it. The men look tired... leaner every week, like they're working double shifts. Maybe they are. Harold never talks about the mine anymore. Every attempt I make leads to an argument.

I don't know what he's hiding, but whatever it is... it's getting worse.

He used to be a kinder man.



I pray he finds his way back.

LIV-N-003-01.description:
THIRTEEN DEAD IN MINE COLLAPSE --- COMPANY CALLS IT 'UNFORESEEABLE'              Rockford County Herald --- August 22, 1974

A partial collapse in the Scarlet Mining Co. shaft system left thirteen confirmed dead, including multiple 'auxiliary assistants,' a term the company declined to clarify.

Representatives denied allegations of unsafe conditions and insisted the collapse was caused by an 'unpredictable geological shift.'

Grieving families gathered outside the mine entrance demanding answers. Some claim the company is withholding information about the cause.

Scarlet Mining Co. has promised a full investigation.

No timeline has been provided.
